title: Article 1
annotation: This source contains the articles of the 1864 Geneva Convention. We used it to prove the theme-topic connection to rights and responsibilities and demonstrate how the drafters and representatives protected individuals during future wars in short-term effects. The source helped us learn about the contents of the main document of our topic and its relation to the theme.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention on Wounded and Sick, 1906
annotation: This source is the articles of the 1906 Geneva Convention. We used the source in short-term effects to explain the contents of the document and how it protected belligerents and civilians. We also used it in long-term effects to help explain the convention and its relation to the theme. We learned about the document, the protections it offered, and its relation to the theme.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention on Prisoners of War, 1929
annotation: This source represents the articles of the 1929 Geneva Convention. We used it for short-term effects to show examples of the document protecting people and long-term effects to explain the convention and its connection to the theme. The source gave us information about the articles, such as their relation to the theme, and their effects, such as shielding certain individuals.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention (IV) on Civilians, 1949
annotation: This source is the articles of the 1949 Geneva Convention. We used the source in long-term effects to help the reader understand the convention and its theme-topic connection and short-term effects to give examples of what is in the document and how this protected people in war. We learned about the contents of the document as well as the ways it protected people experiencing war and its theme-topic connection.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (I) to the Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source contains the articles of Additional Protocol One to the Geneva Conventions. The source was used for short-term effects to relate the document to the protection of individuals. In long-term effects we used the source to communicate the contents of the document and the theme-topic connection. We learned about the protocol and its protections and connections to rights and responsibilities.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (II) to the Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source is the articles of Additional Protocol Two to the Geneva Conventions. We used the source in long-term effects to give information about the document and its theme-topic connection. We also use it in short-term effects to prove that the protocol protected wartime individuals. We learned about the document, its protection, as well as its relation to the theme.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (III) to the Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source is the articles of Additional Protocol Three to the Geneva Conventions. We used the source in long-term effects to explain the document and its theme-topic connection. We also used the source in short-term effects to explain how it protected people. We learned information on the articles, their theme-topic connection, and how they protected people.

title: Henry Dunant, co-founder of the Red Cross
annotation: This image shows Henry Dunant, who was instrumental in creating the Geneva Convention. We will use it in background to show what he looked like. The source helped us understand what the creator of our topic looked like.

title: Convention relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention on Prisoners of War
annotation: This document contains information about the 1929 Geneva Convention. We will use it in effects to discuss the contents of the document. The source helped us learn about what was in the document.

title: Fulgence Niyonteze case
source: National Practice - Military Court of Appeal
annotation: This case demonstrates the application of the Geneva Conventions in modern times. We will use it to show the lasting effects of the conventions on international law.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (I) to the Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source contains the articles of Additional Protocol One to the Geneva Conventions. The source will be used for effects to communicate the contents of the document. We can also use it in theme-topic connection to show that the effects of the first Geneva Convention are related to rights and responsibilities. We learned about the protocol and its theme relation.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (II) to the Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source is the articles of Additional Protocol Two to the Geneva Conventions. We used the source in long-term effects to give information about the document and its theme-topic connection. We also use it in short-term effects to prove that the protocol protected wartime individuals. We learned about the document, its protection, as well as its relation to the theme.

title: Preamble
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (III) to the Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source is the articles of Additional Protocol Three to the Geneva Conventions. We used the source in long-term effects to explain the document and its theme-topic connection. We also used the source in short-term effects to explain how it protected people. We learned information on the articles, their theme-topic connection, and how they protected people.

title: A Memory of Solferino
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is the book that Henry Dunant wrote after watching the Battle of Solferino. We used the source in the home page for a quote from Henry Dunant explaining the motives of the Red cross and introducing the purpose of the Geneva Conventions, which was to decrease suffering. This is the information we learned.

title: A Memory of Solferino
source: A Memory of Solferino by J Henry Dunant
annotation: This source is an image of the cover of Henry Dunant's book. We used it in background while explaining the book and its effects.

title: Reference: VP-CER-N-00017-01
source: Geneva Diplomatic Conference on the Reaffirmation and Development
annotation: This source is an image of the meeting related to the first two additional protocols. We used it at the end of the background section.

title: Bosnian Croat Gen. Tihomir Blaskic sits Thursday in the courtroom at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague
source: U.N. war crimes tribunal clears Bosnian of massacre role
annotation: This source is a picture of Tihomir Blaškić, a defendant in a court case. We will use it in our effects section along with the part about Blaškić’s court case.

title: Painting showing the signing of the original Geneva Convention on 22 August
source: Painting showing the signing of the original Geneva Convention on 22 August
annotation: This source is a painting of the first Geneva Convention drawn at the time. We will use it in background while the first Geneva Convention is being explained.

title: First page of the 1864 Geneva Convention document
source: 1864 Geneva Convention | First page of the 1864 Geneva Conve... | Flickr
annotation: This source is a photo of the first page of the first Geneva Convention document. We will use this image in background after the Geneva Convention is signed and the meeting finishes.

title: Original Geneva Convention of 1864
annotation: This is the original manuscript of the 1864 Geneva Convention, preserved in the Swiss Federal Archives. As a primary source document, it provides direct access to the foundational text that established international humanitarian law. We use this to analyze the exact language and provisions of the first convention.

title: Henry Dunant
annotation: This source is an image of Henry Dunant, the founder of the Red Cross and the person who inspired the creation of the Geneva Conventions. We used it in background to show what Henry Dunant looked like.

title: Blaškić
annotation: This source is a summary of the Prosecutor v. Tihomir Blaškić court case. We will use the source in effects as Blaškić was accused of violating the Geneva Convention to explain what happened in the court case. The source helped us learn about the case and how it was related to the Geneva Convention as an effect of it.

title: Geneva Convention
annotation: This source is a summary of the Geneva Convention document of 1864, the convention that created which is our topic. So, we will use it in background to explain what the main points of the article were and what led up to the convention. The source also taught us all of this information.

title: Geneva Convention on Wounded and Sick
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention on Wounded and Sick, 1906
annotation: This source is a summary of the Geneva Convention document of 1906, which is an effect of the first Geneva Convention as it led to all future conventions. We will use it in effects to explain what the main points of the article were and what led up to and caused the convention. The source also taught us all of this information.

title: Geneva Convention on Prisoners of War
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention on Prisoners of War, 1929
annotation: This source is a summary of the Geneva Convention document of 1929. We will use it in effects to explain what the main points of the article were and what led up to and caused the convention. The source gave us a general idea about the document and what inspired politicians to write it.

title: Geneva Convention (IV) on Civilians
source: IHL Treaties - Geneva Convention (IV) on Civilians, 1949
annotation: This source is a summary of the Geneva Convention document of 1949. We will use it in effects as the creation of the document came from the first Geneva Convention document to explain what the main points of the article were and what led up to and caused the convention. The source also taught us all of this information.

title: Additional Protocol (I) to the Geneva Conventions
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (I) to the Geneva Conventions, 1977
annotation: This source states the most important sections of the 1977 additional protocol 1 to the Geneva Conventions. We will use this source in the effects part of our website to provide the viewer with a general idea of this addition. We also gained an understanding of this protocol from this source.

title: Additional Protocol (II) to the Geneva Conventions
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (II) to the Geneva Conventions, 1977
annotation: This source explains why the 1977 additional protocol 2 to the Geneva Conventions was created and ratified. It also explains the process through which the protocol was adopted and some functions of it. We will use the source in effects to give viewers background information about the protocol. This is also what we gained from visiting the source.

title: Additional Protocol (III) to the Geneva Conventions
source: IHL Treaties - Additional Protocol (III) to the Geneva Conventions, 2005
annotation: This source states the reason people constructed addition protocol 3 of 2005 to the Geneva Conventions as well as what it mainly does. We will use the source in effects to help a viewer become more knowledgeable on this protocol. The source assisted us in observing the issues with previous medical symbols and learning about the red crystal.

title: Additional Protocols to the Geneva Conventions of 1949
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source summarizes what the Geneva Conventions did and uses what they were lacking as reasons for why additional protocols were added to the Geneva Conventions. We will use the source for effects in order to convey this information. The source also informed us about these motives for additions to the convention documents.

title: Fulgence Niyonteze case
source: National Practice - Military Court of Appeal
annotation: This source is a summary of the Fulgence Niyonteze military appeal court case. We will use the source in effects as the defendant Fulgence Niyonteze was found guilty of violating certain Geneva Conventions. The source explains to the reader what happened in court. The source helped us learn about the case and how it was an effect of the Geneva Conventions.

title: Geneva Convention
annotation: This source has summaries of all the Geneva Conventions as well as what led up to the first one. We will use the source in background to explain why the first convention was arranged and what it is. We will also use the source for effects as it has information about all the convention documents, including what led to the creation of some. The source taught us about all of this.

title: Geneva Conventions
annotation: This source contains short statements about the contents of all the Geneva Conventions and the first two additional protocols as well as a map based on which countries agreed to the documents. It also explains what led up to the signing of some of these documents. We will use the source in the title page by placing the map and background and effect for information on some of these agreements. This information and knowledge on which countries agreed to the documents is what we gained from the source.

title: Henri Dunant
annotation: This source is a biography of Henry Dunant’s life. We will use this source in background as he was a major part of what led up to the first Geneva Convention, our topic. This source taught us about him, his part in the creation of the 1864 Geneva Convention, and other noble actions of his.

title: World War II: The Horror of War in Pictures
annotation: This source provides visual documentation of the horrors of World War II, helping to illustrate the importance of the Geneva Convention's protections for civilians and medical personnel during wartime. The images demonstrate the real-world impact and necessity of international humanitarian law.

title: The importance of the Red Cross emblem
Middle East Conflict and Civilian Protection
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This image from ICRC's coverage of Middle East conflicts illustrates modern application of Geneva Convention principles regarding civilian protection. We use this visual to demonstrate the continuing relevance of the convention's humanitarian protections in contemporary conflicts.

title: In the name of mercy give
annotation: This World War I era poster illustrates how the principles of the Geneva Convention influenced humanitarian aid campaigns. The image helps demonstrate the lasting impact of the convention on public consciousness and humanitarian efforts.

title: Gray Ladies of the American Red Cross
annotation: This historical photograph shows the Gray Ladies of the Red Cross at work, illustrating how the Geneva Convention's principles led to expanded roles for women in humanitarian service. The image helps visualize the convention's impact on humanitarian aid development.

title: Ethiopian Conflict
annotation: This Associated Press photograph from the Ethiopian conflict illustrates modern applications of Geneva Convention principles in internal conflicts. The image helps visualize how the conventions continue to shape humanitarian responses in contemporary warfare.

title: Henry Dunant (young)
annotation: This early photograph of Henry Dunant shows the founder of the Red Cross and initiator of the Geneva Convention in his youth, before his experience at Solferino. We use this image to help visualize the key figure behind the convention's creation and to provide historical context.

title: Red Cross Conference on Nuclear Weapons
annotation: This photograph from the Red Cross conference shows modern discussions about applying Geneva Convention principles to nuclear weapons. The image illustrates how the convention continues to evolve in response to new challenges in warfare and international relations.

title: Signing of the Geneva Convention
annotation: This photograph captures the historic signing of the 1949 Geneva Convention, a pivotal moment in expanding humanitarian protections. We use this image to illustrate the formal process of establishing international humanitarian law and the broad international participation in the conventions.

title: Geneva Convention World War II
annotation: This World War II era photograph illustrates the historical context that led to major revisions of the Geneva Conventions. The image helps visualize the wartime conditions that prompted the expansion of humanitarian protections in the 1949 conventions.

title: Middle East: De-escalation and protection of civilians urgently needed
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This article demonstrates the continued relevance and application of the Geneva Conventions in modern conflicts, particularly regarding civilian protection. We use this to show how the principles established by the First Geneva Convention continue to influence humanitarian responses today.

title: Women an Important Part of Red Cross History
annotation: This article discusses the role of women in the Red Cross, particularly the Gray Ladies, showing how the Geneva Convention's principles led to broader humanitarian participation. We use this to demonstrate the convention's impact on expanding humanitarian service opportunities.

title: Ethiopia: Status of western Tigray to be settled by law
annotation: This article covers the Ethiopian conflict and humanitarian concerns, demonstrating the ongoing relevance of Geneva Convention principles in modern internal conflicts. We use this to show how the conventions continue to shape discussions about humanitarian law in contemporary conflicts.

title: Red Cross conference fails to agree on nuclear weapons ban amid global tensions
annotation: This article discusses modern challenges in implementing Geneva Convention principles in the context of nuclear weapons and global tensions. We use this to demonstrate how the convention continues to evolve and face new challenges in contemporary international relations.

title: Geneva Convention
annotation: This comprehensive overview of the Geneva Convention provides historical context and explains its evolution through World War II. We use this source to understand how the conventions adapted to changing warfare and humanitarian needs, particularly focusing on the visual materials that document this evolution.

title: Geneva Convention 1864 - Original Document
annotation: This is the original manuscript of the 1864 Geneva Convention, preserved in the Swiss Federal Archives. As a primary source document, it provides direct access to the foundational text that established international humanitarian law. We use this to analyze the exact language and provisions of the first convention.

title: Bosnian Croat Gen. Tihomir Blaskic sits Thursday in the courtroom at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague
annotation: This source is an image of a war criminal being tried for violating the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced and how they protect people by punishing those who violate them.

title: Bosnian Serb military chief Gen. Ratko Mladic enters the Yugoslav War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague
annotation: This source is an image of a war criminal being tried for violating the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced and how they protect people by punishing those who violate them.

title: Bosnian Serb wartime leader Radovan Karadzic in the court room of the International Criminal Tribunal
annotation: This source is an image of a war criminal being tried for violating the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced and how they protect people by punishing those who violate them.

title: Bosnian Serb wartime leader Radovan Karadzic sits in the court room of the International Criminal Tribunal
annotation: This source is an image of a war criminal being tried for violating the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced and how they protect people by punishing those who violate them.

title: Bosnian Serb wartime leader Radovan Karadzic stands in the court room of the International Criminal Tribunal
annotation: This source is an image of a war criminal being tried for violating the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced and how they protect people by punishing those who violate them.

title: Captured Iraqi soldiers sit in a holding area at a U.S. base camp in the Iraqi desert
annotation: This source is an image of Iraqi prisoners of war being held by the United States during the Iraq War. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions protect prisoners of war and ensure they are treated humanely.

title: Captured Iraqi soldiers sit in a holding area at a U.S. base camp in the Iraqi desert
annotation: This source is an image of Iraqi prisoners of war being held by the United States during the Iraq War. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions protect prisoners of war and ensure they are treated humanely.

title: Captured Iraqi soldiers sit in a holding area at a U.S. base camp in the Iraqi desert
annotation: This source is an image of Iraqi prisoners of war being held by the United States during the Iraq War. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions protect prisoners of war and ensure they are treated humanely.

title: Captured Iraqi soldiers sit in a holding area at a U.S. base camp in the Iraqi desert
annotation: This source is an image of Iraqi prisoners of war being held by the United States during the Iraq War. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions protect prisoners of war and ensure they are treated humanely.

title: Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded in Armies in the Field
annotation: This source is an image of the original 1864 Geneva Convention. We used it in background to show what the original document looked like.

title: Delegates at the 1864 Geneva Convention
annotation: This source is an image of the delegates at the 1864 Geneva Convention. We used it in background to show the people who created the first Geneva Convention.

title: Henry Dunant
annotation: This source is an image of Henry Dunant, the founder of the Red Cross and the person who inspired the creation of the Geneva Conventions. We used it in background to show what Henry Dunant looked like.

title: How the Geneva Conventions Matter
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is an article about how the Geneva Conventions affect the world today. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions continue to protect people in modern conflicts.

title: International Committee of the Red Cross
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is the website of the International Committee of the Red Cross. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Red Cross continues to protect people in modern conflicts and enforce the Geneva Conventions.

title: International Criminal Court
annotation: This source is the website of the International Criminal Court. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced through international courts.

title: International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda
annotation: This source is the website of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced through international courts.

title: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
annotation: This source is the website of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions are enforced through international courts.

title: International Humanitarian Law
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is an article about international humanitarian law. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions form the basis of international humanitarian law and continue to protect people in modern conflicts.

title: International Humanitarian Law Database
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is a database of international humanitarian law treaties. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions have influenced the development of international humanitarian law.

title: Landmark Cases
annotation: This source contains information about landmark cases tried by the International Criminal Court. We used it in long-term effects to show specific examples of how the Geneva Conventions are enforced through international courts.

title: Landmark Cases
annotation: This source contains information about landmark cases tried by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. We used it in long-term effects to show specific examples of how the Geneva Conventions are enforced through international courts.

title: Landmark Cases
source: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
annotation: This source contains information about landmark cases tried by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. We used it in long-term effects to show specific examples of how the Geneva Conventions are enforced through international courts.

title: Meeting of the International Committee for Relief to the Wounded
annotation: This source is an image of the meeting that led to the creation of the Red Cross and eventually the Geneva Conventions. We used it in background to show the origins of the Geneva Conventions.

title: Original 1864 Geneva Convention
annotation: This source is the original 1864 Geneva Convention document from the Swiss Federal Archives. We used it in background to show the original document and its contents.

title: Prisoners of War and Detainees Protected under International Humanitarian Law
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is an article about how prisoners of war are protected under international humanitarian law. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions continue to protect prisoners of war in modern conflicts.

title: Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is the first additional protocol to the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions were updated to address new challenges in warfare.

title: Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is the second additional protocol to the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions were updated to address new challenges in warfare.

title: Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is the third additional protocol to the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions were updated to address new challenges in warfare.

title: Red Cross Ambulance
annotation: This source is an image of a Red Cross ambulance from 1864. We used it in background to show how the Red Cross helped wounded soldiers during the early days of the Geneva Conventions.

title: Red Cross Emblem
annotation: This source is an image of the original Red Cross emblem from 1864. We used it in background to show the symbol that was chosen to protect medical personnel and facilities during wartime.

title: The Battle of Solferino
annotation: This source is an image depicting the Battle of Solferino, which inspired Henry Dunant to create the Red Cross and eventually the Geneva Conventions. We used it in background to show the battle that led to the creation of the Geneva Conventions.

title: The Evolution of the Geneva Conventions
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is an article about how the Geneva Conventions have evolved over time. We used it in long-term effects to show how the conventions have been updated to address new challenges in warfare.

title: The First Geneva Convention: The Campaign for Peace
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is an article about the creation of the first Geneva Convention. We used it in background to explain how and why the first convention was created.

title: The Geneva Conventions and their Commentaries
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source contains detailed explanations of the Geneva Conventions. We used it in long-term effects to explain how the conventions continue to protect people in modern conflicts.

title: The Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their Additional Protocols
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source provides an overview of all the Geneva Conventions and their additional protocols. We used it in long-term effects to explain how the conventions have evolved and continue to protect people in modern conflicts.

title: The Geneva Conventions Today
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source discusses how the Geneva Conventions are applied in modern conflicts. We used it in long-term effects to show how the conventions remain relevant and continue to protect people today.

title: The Geneva Conventions: The Core of International Humanitarian Law
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source explains how the Geneva Conventions form the foundation of international humanitarian law. We used it in long-term effects to show the conventions' lasting impact on protecting people in war.

title: The Original Geneva Convention
annotation: This source is the original 1864 Geneva Convention document. We used it in background to show the original text and provisions of the first convention.

title: Treaties, States Parties and Commentaries
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source is a database of international humanitarian law treaties and their commentaries. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions have influenced international law.

title: War and Law
source: International Committee of the Red Cross
annotation: This source explains how international humanitarian law regulates warfare. We used it in long-term effects to show how the Geneva Conventions help protect people during conflicts.
